text: <extra_id_0> BMP-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induces cell death in human memory B cells and Ramos cells
Next , we wanted to establish whether <extra_id_0> BMP-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also could affect the viability of normal B cells .
Cell viability was determined by propidium iodide ( PI ) staining after culture with or without <extra_id_0> BMP-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for 48 hours .

Interestingly , <extra_id_0> BMP-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> showed a small , but reproducible mean increase of cell death from 17 to 23 % ( n = 5 ; p < = 0 , 003 ) in anti-IgM stimulated <extra_id_0> CD27 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + memory B cells .
Furthermore , Ramos cells showed a mean increase in cell death from 20 to 50 % ( n = 3 , p < 0 , 001 , figure 3 ) after <extra_id_0> BMP-6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> treatment .

In contrast , cell death of total <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + cells ( n = 6 ; p < = 0 , 32 ; data not shown ) or <extra_id_0> CD27 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - IgG - naive B cells was not significantly affected ( n = 5 ; p < = 0 , 65 , figure 2 ) .
